steps.title: Filter Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Filtering Movie Data

For this set of activities, you will need the movie_sample_dataset file.

This can be found in the DATA CLEANING section under the Excel Skills page on Aidan's Central.

Create a New Worksheet

First, create a new sheet named 'Filter Practice' to store your results.

Exercise 1: Basic Filtering

Follow these steps:

  1. Apply a filter to the 'imdb_score' column.
  2. Use the number filter to show only movies with an IMDB score greater than 8.0.
  3. Count the number of movies that meet this criteria.
  4. In your 'Filter Practice' sheet, write the total count of movies with a score > 8.0.
Exercise 2: Multiple Filters

Now, with the first filter still active:

  1. Add a second filter to the 'budget' column for movies with a budget less than $50,000,000.

    You will need to select all columns (Ctrl+A) and apply a filter on all of them at once!

  2. Copy the filtered results (the movie titles, scores, and budgets).
  3. Paste them into your 'Filter Practice' sheet below the count from Exercise 1.

quiz.question: How can you apply multiple filters at once in Excel?
options: You can't - you must choose one filter only
Apply filters to different columns one after another
Create a new sheet for each filter

steps.title: Column Management Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Managing Dataset Columns

Clear any filters from the previous activity before continuing.
Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Column Management'.

Exercise 1: Column Cleanup

For this analysis, we'll delete some data that isn't important. It's best practice to work on a copy of your data.

  1. Identify columns not needed for financial analysis (e.g., 'movie_facebook_likes', 'actors', etc.).
  2. Delete these non-essential columns.
  3. Keep only: movie_title, director_name, gross, budget, imdb_score.
Exercise 2: ROI Calculation

With your cleaned dataset:

  1. Insert a new column called 'ROI' after the last column.
  2. In the first data row of that column, calculate Return on Investment using the formula: (gross - budget) / budget.
  3. Use the Fill Handle (the small square in the bottom-right of the cell) to drag or double-click this formula down for all movies.
  4. Extension: Format this column as a percentage.
  5. Copy your final table (with all remaining columns including ROI) and paste it into your 'Column Management' sheet.

quiz.question: What's the best practice before deleting columns in a dataset?
options: Just delete them - you can always undo
Create a backup or work on a copy of your dataset

steps.title: Find & Replace Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Data Cleanup

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Find and Replace'.

Exercise 1: Countries

Clean up the 'Country' column on your original data sheet:

  1. Use Find & Replace (Ctrl+H).
  2. Find 'USA' and Replace with 'Americas'.
  3. Copy your updated country column to your 'Find and Replace' sheet.
Exercise 2: Missing Data

Handle missing values in the 'budget' column:

  1. Use Go To Special to find all blank cells in the budget column.
  2. With the blank cells selected, type 'No Data' and press Ctrl+Enter to fill them all at once.
  3. Count how many movies are missing budget information.
  4. In your 'Find and Replace' sheet, write the count of movies missing budget data.

quiz.question: When standardizing text data, what's the advantage of using Find & Replace over manual corrections?
options: It ensures consistency across all entries

steps.title: Sorting Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Movie Data Analysis

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Sorting Results'.

Exercise 1: Multi-Level Sort

Identify top-performing directors:

  1. Select all your data (Ctrl+A).
  2. Sort by director_name (A to Z). You may need to tick the 'My data has headers' box first to see the option for director_name.
  3. Add a second level: sort by imdb_score (Largest to Smallest).
  4. Copy the top 10 rows of your sorted data to your 'Sorting Results' sheet.
Exercise 2: Financial Analysis

Analyse movie financial performance with simple sorting:

  1. Sort the original data (you may need to Ctrl+Z and get back the original pre-sorted data) by gross revenue (Largest to Smallest).
  2. Copy the top 5 movies to your 'Sorting Results' sheet and label them 'Highest Grossing Movies'.
  3. Sort the original data by budget (Smallest to Largest). Again, make sure this is the original data. Doing this more than once indicates you should be keeping a backup sheet.
  4. Copy the top 5 movies (lowest budgets) to your 'Sorting Results' sheet and label them 'Lowest Budget Movies'.
Submit Your Work

Once you've completed all exercises, your Excel file should contain these sheets:

  • Filter Practice
  • Column Management
  • Find and Replace
  • Sorting Results

Save your file and submit it on Aidan's Central under the DATA CLEANING section.

quiz.question: When performing a multi-level sort, what happens to rows where the first sort column has identical values?
options: They remain in their original order
They are sorted according to the next level criteria
They are moved to the bottom
